Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is significant on low power electronics, especially in markets for wearable devices and implantable medical devices. As electronic devices continue to shrink in size they are faced with compounded issues of power consumption, heat generation and dissipation. As the devices become more sophisticated and the users of such devices demand more utility and connectivity, a need for providing more functionality with less power consumption, decreased heat management, and extended battery life is in critical demand. The Near-Threshold-Voltage (NTV) modular regulator is adaptable to commercially available integrated circuits and provides an innovative solution to these issues. The commercial impact of this NTV modular regulator technology could be realized by saving power consumption and by cutting expenses in development costs to qualify for new generation of low-power electronics. Similar savings and an even broader impact may be envisioned when the modular designing tool is used for a variety of applications using legacy CMOS circuitry and enabling seamless updates to newer technology without substantial development costs.

This I-Corps project further develops a Near-Threshold-Voltage (NTV) modular regulator that is practical for semiconductor integrated circuit (IC) products. The regulator reduces power consumption of many commercially available ICs by running at slightly higher than NTV regions auto-set by the design. It lowers the IC internal operating voltages and enables them to run smoothly at above 95% regulation while minimizing the noise effects. With this module, the ICs will not require external voltage regulators, which further minimizes the unused space on circuit boards. The module is adaptable to ICs without making expensive and drastic changes to their original VLSI designs, especially avoiding the costly technology process transfers for manufacturers. Many devices utilizing System-On-a-Chip (SoC) architectures will realize the advantages of using this module as part of the layout without changing the core circuitry. As the module is process adjustable by design, the SoC does not need to rely on software solutions to regulate power consumption. With the NTV module, existing ICs can easily adapt to emerging CMOS technologies thus sustaining or reviving their period of performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF iCorps team has explored the commercialization potential utilizing advanced technology developed by the entrepreneur lead in the PI’s laboratory at UTSA under prior support of the NSF. The near threshold voltage (NTV) regulator (patent pending) technology is capable of significantly reducing the power of microelectronic CMOS circuits, controllers and processors. Under laboratory testing, it has been proven that micro-electronics can be driven at 1/5 or lower power than normally required.  NTV applied to batteries-driven devices (mobile phones, IoT, medical implants, etc.), may results in significant extension of battery life per charge, as well as reduced burden for recycling batteries.  This iCorps team project was set out to explore the commercial potential of the technology aiming at rendering substantial gains in power management, possible elimination of the use of separate power management integrated circuit, as well as saving additional cost for silicon space and minimize complexity in engineering resources during design phase.

Intellectual Merit: Supported by this NSF I-Corps program, the potential market needs for a properly applied form of NTV regulator related technology has been surveyed by this team, through a rigorous customer discovery process. A key outcome of this I-Corps program for the team was the understanding of the market segments and streamlining on where to focus in order to improve the chance for establishment of a small business that can be profitable and sustainable.  After more than 100 interviews across the country, the team identified the most feasible market segment to be the electronics systems at devices and component levels.  Opportunities to implement the NTV module technology were further narrowed to specialty fabs, small design houses (without in house Fab or is fabless), and electronic systems and equipment companies, instead of major semiconductor manufacturers.  Based on the finding, the I-Corps Entrepreneurial Lead is now directly involved in commercialization of the technology through a start-up venture.  There are also small market opportunities in non-invasive electronics of medical and health related products and IoT devices, to which the team continues to explore.

Broader Impact: The EL has progressed in academic and potentially entrepreneurship career benefiting from this i-Corps training. The EL is taking on the CTO role and as a partner of a new company established as a result of iCorps supported discovery on the technology.  One undergraduate student (Hispanic minority), who subsequently enrolled in Computer Engineering Graduate Program at UTSA, participated in semiconductor NTV chip testing and gained hands on experience in design and evaluation of semiconductor CMOS devices.  The I-Corps training and the experience has significantly impacted the PI’s thought process and mentorship practice in teaching and research as well.
